# Clinician

## Role information

Clinicians are health care professionals who provide principal care for patients.
There are different types of clinicians, including physicians, nurses, physician assistants, dentists, and clinical pharmacists, amongst other.

Regardless of their background, clinicians share the following commonalities:

- They all have direct contact with patients
- They are all health care professionals who require licensure to work or practice
- They all work in medical settings
- They all help patients manage their conditions and overall health

For the ISNCSCI App project, we are focusing on clinicians who work with patients with spinal cord injuries.

Reyna is a nurse at a spine ward at Vancouver General Hospital.
She has been working at the hospital for 10 years and has been a nurse for 15 years.
She is a senior nurse and is responsible for the training of new nurses.
She is also responsible for the quality of the data collected by the nurses in her ward.
She is very interested in finding ways to improve the quality of the data collected by her team.

Reyna works long hours, all of them full of activities.
Her workloadk increased significantly during COVID, and the demands have not decreased since.
When they are not attending a patient, they are counseling the families of the patients, helping in the operating room or finding candidates for different types of projects.
When they finally have a minute of rest, their beeper lets them know there is another emergency on the way.
Their main priority is their patients, which is why they are very interested in finding ways to improve their care.
Senior nurses have to also work on reports to justify their department's use of resources to Finance.
They typically create the reports in Excel but they would like to have a way to get reports using real data from their site to back up their conclusions and have a better chance at improving the practice and requesting additional resources.

Reyna administers periodical ISNCSCI examinations to patients with spinal cord injuries.
These examinations are laborious and time consuming as many different dermatomes need to be tested for sensation via pin pricks or rubbing a swab on different parts of the body.
An ISNCSCI examination requires 134 different measurements.
These measurements then need to be tabulated in order to produce a classification from an A, B, C, D, and E scale.
While some of the inputs are straight forward and can be represented with numeric values from 0 to 5, other requires the clinicians judgement which makes scoring quite complicated.
After spending time and energy entering the values on the sheet, they prefer to enter the information into automated tools to produce the final scoring.
They, however, need to understand and verify the results.

Reyna is very interested in the ISNCSCI App project because it could help them improve the quality of the data collected by their team and help them find ways to improve the care of their patients.
They are also interested in the possibility of using the data collected by the app to create reports that could help them justify the use of resources to Finance.

### Activities

- Do rounds
- Attend to patients
- Take detailed records of symptoms and medical histories
- Fill in sections of the patient's charts and files
- Suggest patients for research
- Deal with families in distress
- Consent patients for projects
- Monitor patients
- Find ways to improve quality (QI)
- Perform ISNCSCI examinations
- Assist during surgeries
- Train new nurses

### Goals

- Achieve continuous quality improvement
- Provide the best care for patients
- Be efficient in their tasks
- Ensure quality of the data collected
- To be recognized for their hard work

### Use cases

1. Complete an ISNCSCI exam at bedside
2. Enter ISNCSCI information into EMR
3. Review patient progress by comparing ISNCSCI examinations
4. Print ISNCSCI exam results to add to a chart
5. Review ISNCSCI ISNCSCI classification calculated manually
